title: H01-1042

sentences.text: The purpose of this research is to test the efficacy of applying automated evaluation techniques , originally devised for the evaluation of human language learners , to the output of machine translation -LRB- MT -RRB- systems .
We believe that these evaluation techniques will provide information about both the human language learning process , the translation process and the development of machine translation systems .
This , the first experiment in a series of experiments , looks at the intelligibility of MT output .
A language learning experiment showed that assessors can differentiate native from non-native language essays in less than 100 words .
Even more illuminating was the factors on which the assessors made their decisions .
We tested this to see if similar criteria could be elicited from duplicating the experiment using machine translation output .
Subjects were given a set of up to six extracts of translated newswire text .
Some of the extracts were expert human translations , others were machine translation outputs .
The subjects were given three minutes per extract to determine whether they believed the sample output to be an expert human translation or a machine translation .
Additionally , they were asked to mark the word at which they made this decision .
The results of this experiment , along with a preliminary analysis of the factors involved in the decision making process will be presented here .

Entity-this_research.label: this research
Entity-this_research.description: This research aims to evaluate the effectiveness of automated assessment methods, designed for human language learners, in analyzing the intelligibility of outputs from machine translation systems.

Entity-the_result_of_this_experiment.label: The results of this experiment
Entity-the_result_of_this_experiment.description: The results of this experiment refer to the findings obtained from assessing the intelligibility of machine translation outputs compared to expert human translations, as well as the analysis of the decision-making factors influencing subjects' evaluations.

Entity-machine_translation_-lrb-_mt_-rrb.label: machine translation -LRB- MT -RRB- systems
Entity-machine_translation_-lrb-_mt_-rrb.description: Machine translation (MT) systems are automated software applications designed to translate text or speech from one language to another, utilizing various algorithms and techniques to produce translations that can be evaluated for intelligibility and accuracy.

Entity-the_intelligibility_of_mt_output.label: the intelligibility of MT output
Entity-the_intelligibility_of_mt_output.description: The intelligibility of MT output refers to the clarity and comprehensibility of text produced by machine translation systems, as assessed by human evaluators in the context of distinguishing between expert human translations and machine-generated translations.

Entity-extract.label: extracts
Entity-extract.description: The term 'extracts' refers to a set of up to six samples of translated newswire text used in an experiment to evaluate the intelligibility of machine translation outputs compared to expert human translations.

Entity-the_assessor.label: the assessors
Entity-the_assessor.description: The assessors are individuals who evaluate and differentiate between native and non-native language essays, as well as assess the quality of machine translation outputs in the context of language learning and translation intelligibility.

Entity-the_experiment.label: the experiment
Entity-the_experiment.description: The experiment refers to a study designed to evaluate the intelligibility of machine translation outputs by comparing them to expert human translations, where subjects assess the quality of the translations based on specific criteria.

Entity-the_sample_output.label: the sample output
Entity-the_sample_output.description: The sample output refers to the machine translation outputs presented to subjects in the experiment, which they had to evaluate to determine if they were expert human translations or machine translations.

Entity-evaluation_technique.label: evaluation techniques
Entity-evaluation_technique.description: Evaluation techniques refer to automated methodologies originally designed to assess human language learners, which are now being applied to evaluate the output of machine translation systems.

Entity-decision.label: decisions
Entity-decision.description: The term 'decisions' refers to the judgments made by assessors regarding the classification of machine translation outputs as either expert human translations or machine translations, based on specific criteria during an evaluation experiment.

Entity-the_first_experiment_in_a_series_.label: the first experiment in a series of experiments
aliases: the first experiment in a series of experiments
Entity-the_first_experiment_in_a_series_.description: The first experiment in a series of experiments focuses on evaluating the intelligibility of machine translation output by comparing it to expert human translations.

mentions.local_name: the first experiment in a series of experiments

Entity-their_decision.label: their decisions
Entity-their_decision.description: The term 'their decisions' refers to the judgments made by assessors regarding whether a given text extract is an expert human translation or a machine translation output, based on specific criteria identified during the evaluation process.

Entity-three_minute_per_extract.label: three minutes per extract
Entity-three_minute_per_extract.description: The term 'three minutes per extract' refers to the allocated time given to subjects in an experiment to evaluate and determine whether a sample of translated text is an expert human translation or a machine translation.

Entity-the_factor_on_which_the_assessor_.label: the factors on which the assessors made their decisions
aliases: the factors on which the assessors made their decisions
factors on which the assessors made their decisions
Entity-the_factor_on_which_the_assessor_.description: The factors on which the assessors made their decisions refer to the criteria and considerations that evaluators used to distinguish between expert human translations and machine translation outputs during the assessment of intelligibility in translated texts.

mentions.local_name: the factors on which the assessors made their decisions
factors on which the assessors made their decisions

Entity-automated_evaluation_technique.label: automated evaluation techniques
Entity-automated_evaluation_technique.description: Automated evaluation techniques are systematic methods used to assess and measure the quality or performance of outputs, such as language learning or machine translation, through automated processes.

Entity-this_decision.label: this decision
Entity-this_decision.description: This decision refers to the point at which subjects in the experiment determined whether a sample of translated text was produced by an expert human translator or a machine translation system.

Entity-a_set_of_up_to_six_extract_of_tra.label: a set of up to six extracts of translated newswire text
aliases: a set of up to six extracts of translated newswire text
Entity-a_set_of_up_to_six_extract_of_tra.description: A set of up to six extracts of translated newswire text refers to a collection of short segments of news articles that have been translated, used in an experiment to evaluate the intelligibility and quality of machine translation compared to expert human translations.

mentions.local_name: a set of up to six extracts of translated newswire text

Entity-assessor.label: assessors
Entity-assessor.description: Assessors are individuals who evaluate and differentiate between native and non-native language essays based on specific criteria in a language learning experiment.

Entity-non-native_language_essay.label: non-native language essays
Entity-non-native_language_essay.description: Non-native language essays are written works produced by individuals who are not native speakers of the language in which the essays are written, often used for language assessment and evaluation of language proficiency.

Entity-word.label: word
Entity-word.description: In this context, 'word' refers to a specific point in the text where subjects indicated their decision regarding whether a sample output was an expert human translation or a machine translation.

Entity-the_subject.label: The subjects
Entity-the_subject.description: The subjects refer to the participants in the experiment who evaluated translated newswire text extracts to distinguish between expert human translations and machine translation outputs.

Entity-a_preliminary_analysis_of_the_fac.label: a preliminary analysis of the factors involved in the decision making process
aliases: a preliminary analysis of the factors involved in the decision making process
Entity-a_preliminary_analysis_of_the_fac.description: A preliminary analysis of the factors involved in the decision making process refers to an initial examination of the criteria and considerations that influence how subjects differentiate between expert human translations and machine translation outputs in the context of evaluating intelligibility.

mentions.local_name: a preliminary analysis of the factors involved in the decision making process

Entity-mt_output.label: MT output
Entity-mt_output.description: MT output refers to the text produced by a machine translation system as a result of converting source language content into target language content.

Entity-language_learning_experiment.label: language learning experiment
Entity-language_learning_experiment.description: A language learning experiment is a systematic investigation designed to study the processes and outcomes of acquiring a new language, often involving participants engaging in various language tasks to assess their learning progress and effectiveness.

Entity-factor.label: factors
Entity-factor.description: The term 'factors' refers to the specific elements or criteria that influenced the assessors' decision-making process when evaluating the intelligibility of machine translation outputs.

Entity-native_from_non-native_language_e.label: native from non-native language essays
Entity-native_from_non-native_language_e.description: The term 'native from non-native language essays' refers to written compositions that are produced by individuals whose first language is the target language (native) compared to those whose first language is different from the target language (non-native), highlighting the differences in language proficiency and writing quality.

Entity-the_factor.label: the factors
Entity-the_factor.description: The factors refer to the criteria or elements that assessors used to differentiate between expert human translations and machine translation outputs during the evaluation process.

Entity-system.label: systems
Entity-system.description: The term 'systems' refers to machine translation systems that are being evaluated for their output quality using automated evaluation techniques.

Entity-similar_criterion.label: similar criteria
Entity-similar_criterion.description: The term 'similar criteria' refers to the evaluative standards or factors used by assessors to differentiate between expert human translations and machine translation outputs in the context of assessing intelligibility in machine translation.

Entity-the_development_of_machine_transl.label: the development of machine translation systems
aliases: the development of machine translation systems
Entity-the_development_of_machine_transl.description: The development of machine translation systems refers to the process of creating and improving automated systems that translate text or speech from one language to another, focusing on enhancing their accuracy, intelligibility, and overall effectiveness in comparison to human translations.

mentions.local_name: the development of machine translation systems

Entity-machine_translation_system.label: machine translation systems
Entity-machine_translation_system.description: Machine translation systems are software applications that use artificial intelligence techniques to automatically translate text or speech from one language to another.

Entity-translated_newswire_text.label: translated newswire text
Entity-translated_newswire_text.description: Translated newswire text refers to segments of news articles that have been converted from one language to another, which are used in experiments to evaluate the intelligibility and quality of machine translation outputs compared to expert human translations.

Entity-mt.label: MT
Entity-mt.description: MT refers to machine translation systems, which are automated tools designed to translate text from one language to another.

Entity-machine_translation.label: machine translation
Entity-machine_translation.description: Machine translation refers to the automated process of translating text or speech from one language to another using computer software and algorithms.

Entity-they.label: they
Entity-they.description: The term 'they' refers to the subjects participating in the experiment who were tasked with evaluating the intelligibility of machine translation outputs.

Entity-the_word.label: the word
Entity-the_word.description: The word refers to a specific point in the text where subjects indicated their decision regarding whether a translation was produced by a human expert or a machine translation system.

Entity-subject.label: Subjects
Entity-subject.description: Subjects refers to the participants in the study who evaluated extracts of translated newswire text to determine whether they were produced by expert human translators or machine translation systems.

Entity-translation_process.label: translation process
Entity-translation_process.description: The translation process refers to the method and techniques involved in converting text or speech from one language to another, which is analyzed in the context of evaluating both human and machine translation outputs.

Entity-human_language_learning_process.label: human language learning process
Entity-human_language_learning_process.description: The human language learning process refers to the cognitive and developmental mechanisms through which individuals acquire and develop the ability to understand and use language.

Entity-expert_human_translation.label: expert human translations
Entity-expert_human_translation.description: Expert human translations refer to translations of text that are performed by skilled human translators, ensuring high accuracy and cultural relevance.

Entity-human_language_learner.label: human language learners
Entity-human_language_learner.description: human language learners are individuals who acquire and develop proficiency in one or more languages through study, practice, and exposure.

Entity-intelligibility.label: intelligibility
Entity-intelligibility.description: Intelligibility refers to the quality measure of how comprehensible and understandable spoken or written language is to a listener or reader.

Entity-decision_making_process.label: decision making process
Entity-decision_making_process.description: The decision making process refers to the cognitive and psychological activities involved in evaluating options and making choices based on available information and personal or contextual factors.

Entity-experiment.label: experiment
Entity-experiment.description: An experiment is a systematic procedure undertaken to make a discovery, test a hypothesis, or demonstrate a known fact, often involving controlled conditions and variables.

Entity-preliminary_analysis.label: preliminary analysis
Entity-preliminary_analysis.description: A preliminary analysis is an initial examination or assessment of data or factors that provides insights or informs further investigation in a research context.

Entity-research.label: research
Entity-research.description: Research refers to a systematic investigation or study aimed at discovering and interpreting knowledge, often conducted in an academic or scientific context.

summary: The purpose of this research is to test the efficacy of applying automated evaluation techniques , originally devised for the evaluation of human language learners , to the output of machine translation -LRB- MT -RRB- systems . We believe that these evaluation techniques will provide information about both the human language learning process , the translation process and the development of machine translation systems . This , the first experiment in a series of experiments , looks at the intelligibility of MT output . A language learning experiment showed that assessors can differentiate native from non-native language essays in less than 100 words . Even more illuminating was the factors on which the assessors made their decisions . We tested this to see if similar criteria could be elicited from duplicating the experiment using machine translation output . Subjects were given a set of up to six extracts of translated newswire text . Some of the extracts were expert human translations , others were machine translation outputs . The subjects were given three minutes per extract to determine whether they believed the sample output to be an expert human translation or a machine translation . Additionally , they were asked to mark the word at which they made this decision . The results of this experiment , along with a preliminary analysis of the factors involved in the decision making process will be presented here .

Predicate-tests_the_efficacy_of.label: tests the efficacy of
Predicate-tests_the_efficacy_of.description: The predicate 'tests the efficacy of' indicates an evaluative action performed by the subject on the object, where the subject seeks to determine the effectiveness, performance, or impact of the object in a specific context. This involves systematic investigation or experimentation to assess how well the object achieves its intended purpose or outcomes.

Predicate-originally_devised_for_the_eva.label: originally devised for the evaluation of
Predicate-originally_devised_for_the_eva.description: The predicate 'originally devised for the evaluation of' indicates that the subject was specifically created or designed with the primary purpose of assessing or measuring the performance, capabilities, or characteristics of the object. This suggests a foundational intent behind the subject's development, linking it directly to the evaluation process of the object.

Predicate-applied_to_the_output_of.label: applied to the output of
Predicate-applied_to_the_output_of.description: The predicate 'applied to the output of' indicates a relationship where the subject is utilized or implemented in relation to the results or products generated by the object. It signifies that the subject acts upon, evaluates, or processes the output produced by the object, thereby establishing a functional connection between the two entities.

Predicate-provide_information_about.label: provide information about
Predicate-provide_information_about.description: The predicate 'provide information about' establishes a relationship where the subject conveys knowledge, details, or insights regarding the object. It indicates that the subject serves as a source or means through which understanding of the object is enhanced or clarified.

Predicate-will_provide_information_about.label: will provide information about
Predicate-will_provide_information_about.description: The predicate 'will provide information about' indicates a relationship where the subject is expected to convey, share, or supply knowledge, details, or insights regarding the object. This connection implies that the subject has the capacity or authority to inform others about the characteristics, processes, or aspects of the object, thereby enhancing understanding or awareness of the topic at hand.

Predicate-looks_at.label: looks at
Predicate-looks_at.description: The predicate 'looks at' indicates a relationship where the subject is examining, considering, or focusing on the object. It implies an analytical or observational engagement with the object, suggesting that the subject seeks to understand, evaluate, or gain insights regarding the object in question.

Predicate-showed_that.label: showed that
Predicate-showed_that.description: The predicate 'showed that' serves to indicate a demonstration or evidence of a relationship or conclusion between the subject and the object. It implies that the subject provides information, findings, or results that substantiate or clarify the nature of the object, often in a context of research, analysis, or evaluation.

Predicate-can_differentiate.label: can differentiate
Predicate-can_differentiate.description: The predicate 'can differentiate' indicates the ability of the subject to recognize, distinguish, or identify differences between two or more entities or concepts represented by the object. It implies a cognitive process where the subject applies knowledge or criteria to discern variations, classifications, or categories within the specified context.

Predicate-made.label: made
Predicate-made.description: The predicate 'made' indicates an action performed by the subject that results in the creation, formulation, or execution of the object. It implies a process where the subject actively engages in bringing about or establishing the object, often involving decision-making, production, or construction.

Predicate-were_illuminating_for.label: were illuminating for
Predicate-were_illuminating_for.description: The predicate 'were illuminating for' indicates that the subject provided valuable insights, clarity, or understanding to the object. It suggests that the information or elements represented by the subject enhanced the knowledge or perspective of the object, allowing them to grasp concepts or make informed decisions more effectively.

Predicate-elicited_from.label: elicited from
Predicate-elicited_from.description: The predicate 'elicited from' indicates a relationship where the subject generates or produces a response, result, or output that is derived from the object. It suggests that the object serves as a source or basis for the information or data represented by the subject, highlighting a directional flow of influence or causation.

Predicate-were_given.label: were given
Predicate-were_given.description: The predicate 'were given' indicates a transfer of possession or provision, where the subjects receive or are provided with the object. It implies that the subjects are the recipients of something, which is the object, suggesting an action that involves giving or supplying.

Predicate-of.label: of
Predicate-of.description: The predicate 'of' serves to indicate a relationship of belonging or association between the subject and the object. It connects the subject to the object by specifying that the subject is related to, derived from, or characterized by the object, thereby providing context or clarification about the nature of the subject in relation to the object.

Predicate-determine_whether_they_believe.label: determine whether they believed
Predicate-determine_whether_they_believe.description: The predicate 'determine whether they believed' connects the subject to the object by indicating a process of evaluation or assessment regarding the beliefs held by the subjects. It implies that the subjects are engaged in a cognitive or analytical activity aimed at ascertaining the truth or validity of their beliefs, which is reflected in the object. The object represents the outcome or result of this determination, often expressed in a form that indicates the presence or absence of belief.

Predicate-to_be.label: to be
Predicate-to_be.description: The predicate 'to be' serves as a linking verb that establishes an identity or state of existence between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject is defined by or equated with the object, thereby conveying a relationship of equivalence or classification.

Predicate-will_be_presented.label: will be presented
Predicate-will_be_presented.description: The predicate 'will be presented' indicates a future action where the subject is the entity that is going to be showcased or introduced, and the object is the content or information that will be shared or displayed. This construction implies a forthcoming event where the subject serves as the focus of attention, while the object provides the specific details or insights that will be communicated to an audience.

Predicate-supports.label: supports
Predicate-supports.description: The predicate 'supports' indicates a relationship in which the subject provides assistance, validation, or reinforcement to the object. It implies that the subject contributes positively to the understanding, acceptance, or effectiveness of the object, suggesting a foundational or complementary role.

Predicate-evaluates_the_effectiveness_of.label: evaluates the effectiveness of
Predicate-evaluates_the_effectiveness_of.description: The predicate 'evaluates the effectiveness of' establishes a relationship where the subject conducts an assessment or analysis to determine how well the object performs or achieves its intended purpose. This involves measuring, comparing, or analyzing various aspects of the object to provide insights into its efficiency, quality, or overall success.

Predicate-assess.label: assess
Predicate-assess.description: The predicate 'assess' indicates an evaluative action performed by the subject on the object, where the subject examines, analyzes, or judges the qualities, performance, or outcomes represented by the object. This relationship implies a process of measurement or appraisal, often aimed at determining effectiveness, value, or significance.

Predicate-affects.label: affects
Predicate-affects.description: The predicate 'affects' denotes a relationship in which the subject has an influence or impact on the object, resulting in a change or alteration in the state, quality, or condition of the object. It implies a directional effect where the subject's characteristics, actions, or properties modify or determine aspects of the object.

Predicate-evaluates.label: evaluates
Predicate-evaluates.description: The predicate 'evaluates' signifies an action where the subject conducts an assessment or analysis of the object, determining its quality, effectiveness, or performance based on specific criteria or standards.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or category that falls under the more general category represented by the object. This relationship suggests that the object encompasses a wider scope or a more inclusive classification that includes the subject as one of its subcategories.
